medical_info: Mr. Rodriguez presented to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset left-sided weakness and slurred speech while at work. Symptoms began approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. Initial examination revealed left facial droop, left arm drift, and dysarthria with an NIHSS score of 8. CT head showed no acute hemorrhage, and the patient met criteria for thrombolytic therapy. tPA was administered within 3 hours of symptom onset. Following administration, the patient was admitted to the stroke unit for close monitoring. Initial improvement was noted in his facial droop, but left arm weakness persisted. MRI confirmed an acute right middle cerebral artery territory infarct. On day 2, Mr. Rodriguez developed aspiration during a swallow evaluation, necessitating placement of a nasogastric tube for feeding. Speech therapy was consulted for ongoing evaluation and rehabilitation. Blood pressure remained labile, requiring careful titration of antihypertensive medications. A comprehensive stroke workup revealed previously undiagnosed atrial fibrillation as the likely etiology. Anticoagulation with heparin was initiated on day 3, with plans to transition to apixaban prior to discharge. The patient made steady progress with physical and occupational therapy. By day 5, he was able to ambulate with assistance and demonstrated improved left arm strength. Speech therapy noted improvement in swallowing function, allowing for advancement to a soft diet. At discharge on day 8, Mr. Rodriguez had minimal residual facial asymmetry, was tolerating regular diet, and was able to walk independently with a walker. He was discharged to an acute rehabilitation facility for continued intensive therapy.
